author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Techint Faces Multinational Probes - Risk & Compliance Journal. - WSJ
text:
0 COMMENTS The headquarters of Techint stands in Milan, Italy, on Wednesday, Oct. 31, 2007. Photo: Giuseppe Aresu/BLOOMBERG NEWS
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
Global industrial giant Techint faces multinational money-laundering and bribery allegations ; the company allegedly used a web of offshore companies to shuffle money and pay bribes to Brazilian state companies. It denied the allegations, with subsidiaries saying they’d prove their innocence in court and the parent saying an internal probe found no wrongdoing. (ICIJ)
Odebrecht SA said it would fight the debarment imposed by the Mexican government. (VOA)
A Myanmar official was accused of taking $1.1 million in bribes; the story didn’t contain a response. (MM)
Local cases: Former Detroit cops were sentenced for collecting cash bribes. Two former Indonesian local officials were jailed for bribery. The lawyer for a Canadian cop convicted of bribery said he’s considering an appeal. (DFP, JP, Star, TS, CBC)
Cybercrime:
Hong Kong’s privacy commissioner will review a data protection law. (SCMP)
Atlanta spent $26 million to recover from a ransomware attack. (Wired)
North Korea’s elite are quitting social media and concealing their Internet activity, according to a cybersecurity researcher. Activists continue to try to penetrate the so-called Hermit Kingdom. (Reuters, WP)
Iceland’s infamous bitcoin miner thief was arrested . (CD)
Hackers built a master key to unlock millions of hotel rooms. (ZDNet, Reuters)
Money Laundering:
Prosecutors pushed back against claims from Paul Manafort over items seized from a storage locker in his money-laundering case. (ABC)
Sanctions:
French President Emmanuel Macron said he believes the U.S. will walk away from the Iran nuclear deal. (BuzzFeed, Bloomberg)
Aluminum’s gains against steel were dented by the U.S. sanctions on Russia. (Bloomberg)
Is it time to lighten or toughen sanctions on North Korea? (Bloomberg)
A Maltese bank whose former chairman is charged in the U.S. with violating sanctions shut its U.K. location. (document)
Restrictions on Cuba held up business in the U.S. Senate. (McClatchy)
Transparency:
Paradise Papers: Maltese authorities froze 91 bank accounts linked to an investor with ties to Angola’s former leaders. (ICIJ)
General Anti-Corruption:
The chief of staff to Malta’s premier is refusing to answer questions about his relationship with two offshore companies. A Maltese government spokesman wrote a letter to the editor denying the government is hiding the killer of a journalist. (MT, Guardian)
Chinese gold mining in Cameroon is bringing corruption concerns to the surface. (AFP)
There was no corruption at 1MDB, said Malaysia’s premier. (Guardian)
Angola’s president fired the army chief over allegations of corruption. (AFP, AN)
Protests: Guatemalan protesters called on the president to resign over allegations of corruption. Hungarians protested against the premier. (Enca, EA)
There’s a tsunami of corruption in tennis, a review found. (BuzzFeed)
The U.S. State Department condemned corruption in Slovakia. (SS)
Venezuela’s foreign minister linked the arrests of two Chevron executives to a nationwide anticorruption drive. (Reuters)
A Cypriot shell company is being used to lobby Congress and the White House for an Albanian political party. (MJ)
A new report details the acts of corruption by U.S. border agents. (MJ)
Ethics: The son of U.S. Energy Secretary Rick Perry owns an energy investment firm. The Trump Inc. podcast continues . (McClatchy, ProPublica)
News organizations seek access to materials in the U.S. special counsel’s probe. The investigation continues . (WP, TNR, Politico)
